awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH:  Fitness Consequences of Alternative Reproductive Strategies
awd_abstract_narration: Sherman  9520801                              Abstract    Evolutionary theory suggests that behavior should be  adjusted to maximize an individual s fitness.  Species in  which individuals switch between distinct behavior patterns  offer an opportunity to test this hypothesis.  This  dissertation improvement research will contrast the  alternative behaviors of territoriality and wandering in  male water striders. This is a powerful model system because  it is possible to watch single individuals over the course  of repeated behavioral decisions. The research will  determine why alternative behaviors are maintained in the  population, and identify the factors that cue switches  between behaviors.  Behavioral observations of mating  success and electrophoretic analyses of paternity will show  how territoriality and wandering affect number of offspring.  Experimental manipulation of social, individual, and  environmental variables will be combined with behavioral  observations to determine what causes behavioral switches.  The research will increase understanding of the bases of  behavioral decisions and the evolution of alternative  behaviors.
